content: I added test + validator "998+1".

I have fixed a few typos.

I have also tried to improve the overall presentation, but the part with the order of license plates is still compacted.
Tough for a CoC.

Good idea, liked it. But:
1)There is a mistake on the first line, not FB, but FG.
2)I'd suggest to write CAR LICENCE PLATE(on the first, line, again), because i firstly thought about smth like porcelain :)
3)Also I'd mention that when new plate is being generated, numbers change firstly(like previous one was AA-123-BB, the next one will be AA-124-BB), next - last letters, and the last ones change first two letters (I mean, specify the order of changing characters compared to the previous plate)
4) And, to my mind, you should add an example to give a little bit more 
clearance to your goal.
But, anyway definitely upvote!

Interesting idea, I like it.

You should specify the task more clearly, as I only understood it by reading the test cases.
Like: "Given the licence plate of a car and the number of cars, that were registered after that car, calculate the licence plate of the last registered car".
calling "i_1" the current licence plate was misleading to me.

Also mention, that the licence plates are generated in alphabetical order and add a limit for n to the description.

Ok...
Oups ! Wrong order !
I change it immediately...

First version was wrong... new version now !

"car licence pate" fixed
Yet quite easy for a community puzzle... :(
Thx !
You think that for some coders it's 000?

Some published solutions fail, yes.
And it was the case of mine too :D . I tested after viewing the case on the forum, and fixed it.
Bug now...

Same here. :(

In the contribution panel, the statement is rendered with no formatting. And I cannot see the statement at all in the puzzle page.

I wonder if something went wrong when the status for this puzzle changed to accepted.
fixed ! cool !

My first reaction to Stilgart's comment was the usual "what a whiner!" (my reaction to nicola was unnorteworthy disagreement)

But that reminded me of the ground debate: should communities necessarily be harder than clashes?
Should communities necessarily be hard at all? (for whatever definition of "hard")

IMHO, the current system's rigged against anything hard, with major impact on community puzzles. Anything easy gets approved fast or very fast. Anything hard doesn't get approved at all, or bypassing the usual 3-moderator vote.
Anything in-between stays in limbo, but with more debate.

The rare people who actually approve the hard problems tend to rail against anything easy.
The overwhelming majority of people who approve easy problems don't lift a little finger on hard ones.
[the vast majority of *people* who moderate anything do so without constructive commenting, let alone editing or improving]

Ever since XP got introduced, community/clash authoring could be argued to go by market norms, and they're heavily leaning towards getting trivial problems in. From an authour's viewpoint, they're an enormously better source of XP per time spent.
And the moderation payout is slanted in their favor anyway. There's XP to be made for being in the majority, FFS, so whoever votes first tends to decide. Refusal is a tough step for most, as most societal human values discourage rejection, and in all honesty there's next to no guideline. Approval provides the slight element of pride "I was good enough to solve this".
No wonder the easy stuffs gets through.

Source: authored an arguably broad spectrum of puzzle difficulty. (and didn't even bother working on more "hardest", because system)



BTW, thanks to the both of you for being the occasional yet usual "first-triers" on the harder ones of mine :D

Why not giving super moderators (levelâ©¾29) the ability to directly validate a puzzle or a CoC?
I thought about something (like CodeAbbey): the more the puzzle is solved, the less you have CG points but it needs CG points to be recalculated every time.

JBM: My issue here is that I don't know what to do with this good puzzle.

I think that it is too hard for a 5min CoC.
I think that solving it is not worth 50XP (according to my own idea of XP).
So I didn't want to vote here... But as you said, with a reasoning like this, this puzzle will stay in limbo. :(

Why not giving points according to the toughness of the puzzle like the regular ones (ie 5 times less)?
The toughness might depend on the number of solvers and % of success, or will be estimated by the staff (like Project Euler) or by the moderators.

Good! But there is still FB in the first line) - you wrote '... with (ab,fB,between....', but i guess there must be fG :)
And in the last line.. Fix "ca..." to the "car..."
fixed ^^
